To develop an econometrics model that examines the hedging and safe haven properties of Bitcoin, Ethereum, Gold, and Silver against the S&P500 index, you can follow these steps:

1. Collect data: Collect daily price data for Bitcoin, Ethereum, Gold, Silver, and the S&P500 index for the period May 2018 to 2020.
2. Test for stationarity: Conduct unit root tests (such as the Augmented Dickey-Fuller test) on each time series to determine whether they are stationary or not. If any of the series are found to be non-stationary, transform the series (e.g., by taking first differences) to make them stationary.
3. Test for cointegration: Conduct a cointegration test (such as the Johansen test) to determine whether there is a long-term relationship among the variables. If cointegration is found, it suggests the existence of a long-term equilibrium relationship among the variables.
4. Run OLS regression: Conduct an OLS regression of each cryptocurrency, gold, and silver on the S&P500 index to estimate the coefficients of the relationship between each asset and the index. You can also include additional explanatory variables if relevant.
5. Test for Granger causality: Conduct Granger causality tests to examine the causal relationship between each asset and the S&P500 index. This can help determine whether the assets have hedging or safe haven properties.
6. Run GARCH models: Estimate GARCH models for each asset to examine the volatility of the returns. This can help determine whether the assets have a hedging or safe haven role during times of market stress.
7. Compare results: Compare the results of the OLS regression, Granger causality tests, and GARCH models to determine which assets have better hedging and safe haven properties against the S&P500 index.

To compare the OLS results to the cointegration results, you can look at the coefficients and statistical significance of each model. If cointegration is found, it suggests a long-term relationship between the variables, while the OLS regression estimates the short-term relationship. If the OLS regression coefficients are statistically significant and consistent with the cointegration relationship, it suggests that the short-term relationship is in line with the long-term relationship.

To compare the GARCH results with the OLS and cointegration results, you can examine the volatility of each asset's returns during periods of market stress. If an asset's returns are less volatile during periods of market stress, it suggests that the asset has a safe haven role. Conversely, if an asset's returns are more volatile during periods of market stress, it suggests that the asset has a hedging role.

The data sets you need include daily price data for Bitcoin, Ethereum, Gold, Silver, and the S&P500 index for the period May 2018 to 2020. You may also want to include additional economic variables (such as interest rates or inflation) that could affect the returns of each asset.
